content: The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" is cited as the short title. It includes a temporary deduction for certain mortgage counseling under section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows individuals to deduct up to $500 for qualified mortgage counseling provided by an FHA-accredited organization before obtaining a loan on their principal residence. The deduction for mortgage counseling under the "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" is not allowed for loans not secured by the taxpayer's principal residence. The deduction is terminated for amounts paid after December 31, 2012. Additionally, a new deduction is allowed for mortgage counseling under section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by section 224 apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. A new deduction for upside-down mortgages is added under section 225 of the Internal Revenue Code. The deduction allowed for individuals is 20 percent of the excess acquisition indebtedness over the valuation of the principal residence, limited to $5,000 per year. Fraudulently obtained mortgages are not eligible for this deduction. The deduction for individuals is limited to $5,000 per year and excludes fraudulently obtained mortgages. The deduction is not allowed for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2009. The deduction for upside down mortgages under section 224 is included in the table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by section 225 apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. A new section 25E provides a credit for certain home purchases. A credit is allowed for individuals purchasing a qualified principal residence, equal to 10% of the purchase price or $7,500 ($9,000 in high-cost areas). The credit is divided equally over two taxable years. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited to purchases made within 2 taxable years, starting from the year of purchase. The credit is subject to limitations based on the date of purchase and the individual's modified adjusted gross income. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is subject to limitations based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The credit amount allowable is reduced based on a ratio of the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income over a certain threshold. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' is the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the taxable year plus any excluded amounts. The credit allowed for a taxable year is limited by the regular tax liability and other credits, excluding specific sections. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is subject to limitations based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited by the sum of allowable credits under this subpart for the taxable year. If a credit is claimed for one qualified principal residence, no credit can be claimed for another in the same year by the individual or spouse. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited if a credit has been claimed for another residence in the same year by the individual or spouse. A qualified principal residence is defined as any residence purchased to be the principal residence of the purchaser. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is limited if a credit has been claimed for another residence in the same year. A qualified principal residence means any residence purchased to be the principal residence of the purchaser. No credit is allowed if a credit is already claimed under another section. If the taxpayer disposes of the qualified principal residence or fails to occupy it as their principal residence within 24 months of purchase, the remaining credit will be disallowed. If a taxpayer disposes of or fails to occupy a qualified principal residence within 24 months of purchase, the remaining credit will be disallowed. Special rules apply for joint purchases, with adjustments for married individuals filing separately and unmarried individuals. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence can be allocated among unmarried individuals, with a maximum total credit of $7,000. Rules similar to those for purchase and reporting requirements apply. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence can be allocated among unmarried individuals, with a maximum total credit of $7,000. Rules similar to those for purchase and reporting requirements apply. Additionally, there are basis adjustment provisions for the residence's basis if a credit is allowed. Conforming amendments have been made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to accommodate these changes. Amendments have been made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including sections 25E, 25B, and 25D. Section 1016 now includes a new paragraph related to section 25E(g). Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes to sections 1400C(d)(2) and the addition of a new paragraph related to section 25E(g). Section 25E provides a credit for certain home purchases, with amendments applying to purchases in taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment is subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Additionally, a temporary additional standard deduction for real property taxes is introduced for nonitemizers. In 2008 or 2009, a real property tax deduction is added to the Internal Revenue Code, allowing taxpayers to deduct eligible state and local real property taxes up to $500 ($1,000 for joint filers). The real property tax deduction allows taxpayers to deduct eligible state and local real property taxes up to $500 ($1,000 for joint filers), with specific criteria for the taxes to be eligible. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. SEC. 6 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude unemployment compensation from gross income for individuals in 2008 and 2009. This exclusion applies to amounts received after December 31, 2007.
